Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2008 06:47AM Misty1 wrote: I finished TCH on 9/30 and had some of those same SEs.  Now, I just go for the Herceptin alone.  Not as much fatigue, though.  Once you start losing hair(including nose hairs!), your nasal passage will get sore.  I used a Q-tip and put some Neosporin on the inside of both sides.  This helped greatly!! Good luck with your TXs! ~Misty
Posts.Title: runny nose, head "in a barrel" se's of TCH? rayhope talbrig13

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2008 03:42AM Misty1 wrote: Hi, I hope my answers will help you.  I dreaded this, but it actually turned out to be okay.  I had already had a .6 tumor removed in an excisional biopsy.  when I had an MRI, they found another suspicious lesion, but this turned out to be B9.  That is why I had this type done.  My husband took me, so that allowed them to give me a little something to take the edge off beforehand.  I would ask for this if Iwere you. How much will it hurt? I felt very little pain. How much will the lidocaine shots hurt, and how deep do they go? I am very small, and the lump was not very deep. How deep does the core needle (is that what it's called) go? same as other ? Do they insert the core needle more than once, and in more than one place? She makes a little cut for the core to go in, so if she put it in more than once, I did not feel it. Will it hurt when the lidocaine wears off? How much, compared to, say, dental work? I felt very little pain from it afterwards.  I went on with my normal day. Will I have a bandage over it, or just a bandaid? For how long? I kept the bandage on it for two days.  It looked like a little cut afterwards. Will it scar? I chose to have a mastectomy because they had to go back in to get rid of some DCIS from the original excisional biopsy.  So, that cut came off with some skin.  Please don't worry too much about the procedure, it wasn't that bad.  The nurses held my hand and made me feel better the entire time.  Speak up if you feel pain.
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy w/ U/S, what to expect? CorasMama Jo_Ann_K

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2008 06:19AM Misty1 wrote: Hi LadyJane, I just finished my chemo on 9/30-I did four rounds, three weeks apart.  I am still going for Herceptin every three weeks because of being HER2+.  I am an elementary school teacher.  I went back to work in August in the middle of treatment.  I wear a wig.  I didn't even tell my whole staff, just some close friends and the admin.  I did fine, and did not have to take off any days, except 1/2 days to finish the chemo.  I just did my reconstruction surgery last Wed., so I am off through T'Giving.  Depending on what treatment you have, work should be manageable.  I was very careful about germs being around the kids.  I am near you in Columbia, MD. ~Misty
Posts.Title: working with children ladyjane54 Onehalf

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 09:16PM Misty1 wrote: Hi Jen, I have done 12/18 Herceptin treatments.  I go every three weeks for 90. min. infusions instead of weekly for 30 min. infusions.  As someone mentioned, you will get a heart echo every three months to monitor your heart ejection.  I also notice a drippy nose-feels like water coming out and a tiredness that night.  I have had no other side effects so far.   I did get my first four Herceptins with chemo(Taxotere/Cytoxin.)  Herceptin is more effective when given with chemo or after chemo. All in all, it's a walk in the park compared to the chemo part.  I look at it as my time to put my feet up and read for 90 min. without anyone bothering me!! ~Misty
Posts.Title: Herceptin treatment?? Junebug40 Misty1

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2009 01:30PM Misty1 wrote: Ditto what Yellowrose said for me! ~Misty
Posts.Title: Mastectomy - Lymph nodes taraleec comingtoterms

Posts.Content: Misty1 wrote: Good Morning, I post on the Chemo Aug'08 group.  But, I am hoping some friends who have already gone through this can give me some help.  I am doing 4 Taxotere, Cytoxin, Herc. treatments.  I have already done two-the last on 8/21.  I have not been having many SEs-still working, going to the gym...  But, the eating and appetite are taking a beating.  I am having a hard time wanting to eat anything.  I am eating, but I am not enjoying food and am avoiding most things that I usually like.  I can eat toast for breakfast with milk, but after that, I never know what to eat.  My onc says this should go away in a couple of days, but it is now day 10, and I don't feel like it is getting any better.  What did you do if you had this problem?  I keep hearing about people chewing on ice during treatment.  What is that for?  Would that help with this problem when I go for 3 and 4? Thanks for any suggestions! ~Misty Dx 6/19/2008, IDC, Left, <1cm, Stage IB, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ (FISH) Surgery 7/2/2008 Lymph node removal: Sentinel; Mastectomy; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement Targeted Therapy 7/30/2008 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Chemotherapy 7/31/2008 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 11/18/2008 Reconstruction (left): Silicone implant; Reconstruction (right): Silicone implant Hormonal Therapy 11/25/2008 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Surgery 5/20/2016 Prophylactic mastectomy: Right; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2009 08:09PM Misty1 wrote: Amuta, you will probably get a lot of responses here because so many of us had to go through that type of treatment.  However, I would also suggest you visit some of the monthly chemo groups on this board section.  You will hear exactly what women experience as they go through their treatments. Best wishes to you and your mom.  You are being so supportive by seeking information.  The women on any of these monthly threads are strong and will provide anything you want to know. ~Misty

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2008 04:15PM Misty1 wrote: I just got done 4 cycles of taxotere/cytoxin/herceptin on 9/30.  I will continue to get herceptin through July. My onc said that 4 rounds of this is just as good as AC from a study done last year.  I had no nodes involved.  I just did this to prevent recurrence being HER2+++. ~Misty

Posts.Content: Misty1 wrote: I spent a lot of time on this site back in 2008/2009 when I was diagnosed at the age of 40. Just celebrated my 7 year cancerversary. Unfortunately I am back, but here on behalf of my 73 yo mom. She went for a biopsy last week, and just got the dreaded call tonight. Doctor told her it was caught very early. She did not hear many details... I will be going with her to all of the appts and hope she has just as good of an outcome as I had. Just so hard to see her have to go through this. Brings back some very bad memories for me. Anyway, I'll be checking in from time to time. Really have to think what is going on, since her mom was diagnosed in her 70's I had genetic testing three years back and it was negative. I started 4 TC chemos in August.  I continued to work every day despite the TXs.  I finished TC on 9/30 and now just do every three weeks of Herceptin.  I am so glad I went back to work-kept me busy.  I had to be careful around the kids because of germs. Good luck! `Misty

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 02:36PM Misty1 wrote: You are in the worst phase of this whole nasty disease.  The "not knowing" and "waiting" parts are horrible!!  It sounds like you are going to have a lot of support during this journey.  I hope you get your questions answered soon.  Believe it or not, it does get better once you have a game plan. Take care, `Misty
Posts.Title: Beating the What Ifs tweetyspal Victorious_One

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 05:31PM Misty1 wrote: Hi, I just wanted to tell you to go to the Sept. 08 chemo group on this topic.  I am in the Aug. 08 group, even though I started 7/31.  I also am doing tax/cytox/herc. I am doing the chemo for four rounds and the herc will continue for every three weeks through next July.  You may want to go back and read the posts on that board, too.  You will learn a lot of great information and hear from strong ladies who will share their experiences. I just went through the third round and have my last on 9/30.  All in all, the time has gone quickly.  Has it been fun?  no, but it is doable and you will get through it!!  Just think, you should be done the chemo part by Thanksgiving!! Good luck and I hope you learn alot from these threads!! ~Misty
Posts.Title: starting chemo 24 2008 dblinch Misty1

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 10:10PM Misty1 wrote: Wow, Eric.  I am sure you will hear from some guys.  From a wife's perspective and from what I experienced in these last eight months, my husband was my rock.  He went to every appt, asked questions, supported me at home...  That will be the best thing you can do for your wife.  You will get past this little hurdle in life.  However, it may not seem that way to you right now.  It sounds like she will have all of your support, and that is so important.  Realize that she will be scared, she will cry a lot, and worry about things that seem so miniscule to others. Best wishes, Misty
Posts.Title: Really love Really love my wife of 20 yrs and w breast cancer EricB ladurbi

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2008 01:14PM Misty1 wrote: Hi Girls, I wandered onto your thread.  I am in the Aug. 2008 group.  I finished TC x 4 on 9/30.  I just want to tell all of you to have strength, a good attitude, and stay as active as possible.  Yes, you will probably lose your hair and experience some SEs, but keep crossing off those days on the calendar and you'll be at the end before you know it.  I did not have that hard of a time with TC-I kept working (teaching) and going to the gym.  The worst part for me was the taste bud changes that occur from day 4-11.  My hair is coming in now-I have about 1/2".  I continue to get Herceptin every three weeks, but there are no SEs with this.  So, I am cheering for all of you and hope your time goes fast.  Life on the other end is very good-keep your chins up!!! PM if you want to know anything else!!  These boards are such a lifeline!! You will make some close connections within your group. ~Misty
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2009 03:25PM Misty1 wrote: I am surprised as well that you did not get offered TCH.  I did taxotere, cytoxin, and Herceptin x 4.  Then, I just got the Herceptin every three weeks for the year.  I just got back today from my last Herceptin (WOO-HOO)  It does come to an end!! As for the AC, be careful because the Herceptin can also cause heart issues.  You will be monitored every three months with a heart test to check the output. Your pathology is very similar to mine.   Good luck with your choice.  I am sure you will make the right one that feels best for you. ~Misty
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy Treatment AC versus TH manue manue

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2008 06:38AM Misty1 wrote: Good luck, Denise. I just finished 4 TX's of TC on 9/30.  Like you, I filtered what I read and tried to be positive once it got going.  I had very few problems and was able to work, exercise, and lead somewhat of a normal life!! All the best!  Believe it or not, your time will go fast and it will be over before you know it. ~Misty
Posts.Title: Getting ready to start Taxotere and Cytoxan Onehalf Onehalf

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 02:50PM Misty1 wrote: I had a Wendy's frostie every now and then.  I lived on instant vanilla pudding and Carnation vanilla instant breakfast.  Chocolate was a NO GO!!!  Try those-vanilla seemed to be a very neutral flavor. Oh, forgot about a baked potato-nice and soft. The lack of food taste and appetite was the worst part of chemo-you will appreciate food so much after you recover from your last round!! Good luck. Misty
